tr.td: Title:Fundamental physics with the brightest southern QSO at redshift > 1

body.div: QSO absorbers are precise probes of variations in the fine-structure constant, alpha. While Keck/HIRES spectra suggest a varying alpha, other groups claim smaller VLT/UVES samples support no variation. Varying-alpha estimates from single, high S/N absorbers allow critical assessment of analysis methods and possible systematic errors. The z_abs=1.1508 absorber towards HE0515-4414 (the brightest southern QSO at z>1) is almost ideal for this. However, its unusual complexity has severely affected 3 groups' attempts to fit multiple velocity-component model absorption profiles, invalidating their varying-alpha constraints. We propose to triple the UVES spectral resolution with bHROS which, combined with S/N=50 per spectral pixel, will allow unambiguous determination of the absorption velocity structure. bHROS's wavelength stability will then provide the tightest, most robust single-absorber bound on varying-alpha. bHROS will also strongly limit any departure of the Mg & C isotopic abundances from terrestrial values in this absorber.
